comments.content: Windows cannot check for OS updates, no reason to disconect the ethernet. The question is not clear at all.
Since they can access some websites, there is limited connectivity. Malware is possible so quarantine is likely the best first move.
but how do we know its really a malware question? stupid compTIA likes to leave important shit out.....why do we have to assume all the time?
but it can also be just a "driver issue" instead of malware, isn't it?
Program windows opening and closing on their own is a common sign of malware operating in the background.

discussion.content: Assuming this is a malware troubleshooting question, the first step is to quarantine/isolate the system. Going to driver rollback seems counter to normal troubleshooting procedure or dealing with malware. As weirdly phrased as it is, D is perhaps the best answer to isolate the system from the network.

Given the situation described, the technician should first unplug the Ethernet cable. 

This action is essential because it helps isolate the device from the network and prevents any potential malware or unauthorised access. 
(Options D)
By disconnecting the Ethernet cable, the technician can quarantine the system and prevent further issues. 

Other options, such as rolling back driver updates or resetting Internet Options, are not as critical in this scenario

Selected Answer: D
I had this question on another platform. The answer is D. This is sinton of a malaware and the first thing to do is to isolate the device

No need to rollback drivers as there is no mention of defective screen, keyboard, mouse etc. So the hardware appears fine. Defective keyboard? Not relevant. Since the users cannot check for OS updates and program windows close/open unexpectedly, it isn't just an issue with the browser so Internet Options wouldn't have a huge impact. I'd go with unplugging the Ethernet as this is potentially malware and the system needs to be quarantined/disconnected.

Selected Answer: D
D. Unplug the Ethernet cable.
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine the infected systems. (D)

Key word here is "FIRST". Whenever troubleshooting I check hardware first. D would make the most sense in this case, even though simply unplugging the cable won't do much by itself, but it may be badly worded
i'm sure A is not correct, you should disconect the pc from the network first
the answer is Unplug the Ethernet cable because may be some one accessing your PC

Which of the following tasks should the technician perform "FIRST"?
This has multiple symptoms that appear to be a malware issue. Therefore D seems to be correct

I'd say this is D tbh. It could be drivers i guess, but it seems quite unlikely.

Program windows sometimes open and close without user intervention. - OK so keyboard/mouse drivers possibly but would be an unusual symptom

Windows cannot check for OS updates, and some websites are not accessible - Would mean your NIC drivers are also fried.

It is possible that updates could do this kind of damage to your PC (windows has a bad reputation for this) but seems odd that multiple drivers went bad with (i assume) one update.

The far more likely scenario is that it is a malware infection, in which case the symptoms have already been identified (they give you them in the question), so the next step in the malware removal process would be to isolate the machine (pull the ethernet cable).
I really wish these answers provided explanations, because I can't understand the logic of A being the answer.
why A?

questions.question_text:
A technician is working on a desktop computer that is not performing as expected. Program windows sometimes open and close without user intervention.
Windows cannot check for OS updates, and some websites are not accessible. Which of the following tasks should the technician perform FIRST?

choices.C: Reset all the settings in the Internet Options.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is used with WPA2-Enterprise to authenticate wireless clients?

discussion.content:
Settings such as WPA2 for the Enterprise assume you’ll enable authentication by using something called a RADIUS server (see Figure 20-18). Larger businesses tend to need more security than a single network-wide password can offer. Their networks often require individual users to log in with their own credentials.
-Mike Meyers ebook
I can see Radius is the only possible answer after some googling.

TACACS+ is use for admin access to routers or switches, RADIUS is for remote network users
Source: https://www.google.com/search?q=tacacs%2B+vs+radius&rlz=1C1CHBF_enCA896CA896&oq=TACACS&aqs=chrome.1.69i57j69i59l2j0i67l3j0i512l4.2778j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8

is it A?
Terminal Access Controller Access Control System (TACACS) is a security protocol that provides centralized validation of users who are attempting to gain access to a router or NAS
It's definitely RADIUS
why not A? TACACS+ is also an authentication protocol

choices.A: Report the request to the board.
choices.B: Document the change in the project notes.
choices.D: Perform the RAM upgrade as requested.
choices.C: Consult the back-out plan for guidance.

discussion.content: I think A is the correct answer

Following change management best practices, a technician should document the change in the project notes. This step ensures that the RAM upgrade request is properly recorded and tracked as part of the upgrade process. By documenting the change, the technician maintains a clear record for future reference and ensures transparency in the upgrade process.
They want to keep the hardware while still going through with the upgrade. Rollback is incorrect

The answer is C because the upgrade IS happening which means a back up plan was made beforehand. It will say whether or not keeping the old RAM is ok or not. Since a plan is already in place, We would have to back out of the current plan because this was not part of the plan and we need to possibly make new changes to the plan if it adversely effects our backout plan.
Another wrong answer
Why isn't it A?

comments.content:
If the plan has already been approved by the board and you've already started implementation, C is the best answer. If it hasn't been approved, it's probably both B and A and you have to delve into CompTIA brainism.
The whole Change Management question cluster is just that... a cluster. As in clusterf***. CompTIA seems to have done an especially lousy job with these questions. But, you only need a 71%. Do your best to focus on the 6 parts of Change Management (maybe 7 depending on your learning materials), but focus on other dump areas if you haven't already tested yet.
Good luck either way!

questions.question_text: A company is upgrading the desktops of all its employees. Users in the multimedia department would like to keep the RAM from their current desktops to upgrade their new devices. Following change management best practices, which of the following actions should a technician perform NEXT?

Which of the following types of social engineering threats is this?

socially engineered your attack. relationship or proximity to the company's dumpster, qualifies as social engineered attack

comments.content: I got this question on the test

discussion.content: While I agree this can be labeled as dumpster diving, I don't think it necessarily fits under social engineering.

questions.question_text: A user opens a phishing email and types logon credentials into a fake banking website. The computer's antivirus software then reports it has quarantined several temporary Internet files. A technician disconnects the computer from the network. Which of the following should the technician perform NEXT?

discussion.content: UGH! They need to give references for some of these answers

comments.content: it's phishing, so the first thing to do is the password change. it has nothing to do with quarantine etc.
I agree. His bank account is in serious danger.

discussion.content:
why is not A? the password is not more safe, we are talking about internet banking!
be sure the account is safe again and then mind on other problems

(Options A) - The next step the technician should perform is not disabling the user's local computer account. Instead, they should take the following actions:
1. Change Password
2. Scan and Clean
3. Monitor Accounts
4. Educate the User
5. Review Security Policies
Remember that disabling the user’s local computer account is not a recommended step in this scenario. Instead, focus on securing the user’s accounts, cleaning the system, and educating the user to prevent similar incidents in the future.
the only way I see C as the correct answer is if CompTIA considers disabling the local user account part of isolating it from the network in this instance.

this is about phishing, it's not asking for malware and virus procedures. Since the scenario is about typing banking info to a phishing website the first thing you want to do is change your password. isolating the PC from the network has nothing to do with it

Selected Answer: A
A. Have the user change the password.
Change the username and password immediately using a clean device before they steal all your money! Hurry up!

I think the answer is correct. They said what will the technician NEXT. Maybe he already changed the password for the user ( as it is the FIRST thing to do ). After that its the computers turn - so then he disconnected it from network and then the NEXT possible answer would be Disable the users account.

Answer is A

 CompTIA A+ removing malware steps:
1. Identify/research symptoms
2. Quarantine (remove from network)
3. Disable system restore
4. Remediate infected system (change passwords, perform data backups, etc)
5. Schedule scans and run updates
6. Enable restore (manually create a restore point)
7. Educate the user.
Disable the users account because the user typed in his logon credentials.
Ha has already idetifies the Symptoms, quarentine, he need to run scan and disinfect the system guys . Im going with B.
ANS: Have the user change the password first then make any research does the link have any backdoor excite on the pc
ANS: Have the user change the password first then make any research does the link have any backdoor excut on the pc

IF the PC is disconnected from the network, what's the point of disabling the user account? "Have the user change the password" would make more sense if it said, "Have the user change the banking website password" Maybe in Comptia land, that's what it means? But, how can any password be changed if the PC is unplugged from the network?!?!?!? 

too many assumptions to this question
C <make sense since he has disconnected, he can run anti virus then change password.

comments.content: upon second thought that dont make sense either

discussion.content: Most of the temporary internet files were quarantined so changing password is not the answer..... disabling the local account will help remediate the problem
which they would explain the logic of these answers lol
Why not A?

comments.content: I agree. The normal malware procedure would be disable system restore and then remediation but in this specific case, common sense is you have them change their credentials and inform the bank (even thought that's not an option). Not sure how local account is relevant here.
CompTIA does not ask for common sense that's where they get you.

choices.C: Disable the user's local computer account.
choices.B: Update the antivirus software and run scans.
choices.A: Have the user change the password.
